node.title: Omicron Is Spreading Rapidly Through California
node.alt: A coronavirus testing site in Los Angeles on Tuesday.
node.description: More than 20 percent of coronavirus tests have come back positive over the past week, according to the statewide average.
node.content: ["How fast is the coronavirus spreading in California?", "1. A considerable spike in new cases over the holiday weekend \u2014 nearly a quarter million \u2014 was reported by the state health department on Tuesday, with an average of nearly 59,000 cases a day recorded from New Year\u2019s Eve through Monday. The rate of new cases has soared to 134 per 100,000 residents, and is poised to obliterate the peak set last winter.", "2. Transmission has set a record, blowing even past the heights of 2020, the California Department of Public Health reported on Tuesday. State computer models show the virus moving so quickly in Los Angeles County that roughly two people are being infected by every carrier.", "3. Test positivity has shot up by 1,000 percent in a month. More than 20 percent of coronavirus tests have come back positive over the past week in California, according to the statewide average. At the start of last month, the seven-day average test positivity rate was a little over 2 percent.", "Why so swift? The Omicron variant, mostly. But also holiday gatherings. The variant appears to produce less severe cases, but its spread is particularly bad timing as schools reopen after the winter break.", "Alex Cherniss, the superintendent of the Palos Verdes Peninsula Unified School District, where about 10,000 students in coastal Los Angeles County returned to classrooms this week, told me on Tuesday that school attendance dropped by about 10 percent on Monday as testing of students and staff detected about 170 coronavirus infections.", "About 70 were among children who had already come back to campus, he said, and each had secondary contacts who also had to be sent home. Earlier in the academic year, he said, perhaps 3 percent of students would have returned from a break with an infection. A county health official, he said, told him to assume that a tenth of his student body had the virus \u2014 roughly 1,000 children.", "As Dr. Bob Wachter, chair of the department of medicine at the University of California, San Francisco, put it in a New Year\u2019s Eve tweet: \u201cBe super careful \u2014 it\u2019s raining Covid.\u201d And yet in an interview this week, Wachter also was bullish on California\u2019s prospects. Here\u2019s some of our chat, edited and condensed:", "We\u2019ve got a pretty terrible period ahead of us. The question is how long it lasts, and how bad it gets. We now have pretty good evidence that Omicron is a substantially less severe virus than Delta, particularly in people who\u2019ve been vaccinated. And we\u2019re seeing a disconnect between the number of cases, which are enormous, and the numbers of hospitalizations and people in intensive care units who are really sick.", "I think February and March are going to be OK, and maybe even very good. The way Omicron is acting, the levels of immunity, the fact that many unvaccinated people are going to get their immunity the hard way, through infection \u2014 there\u2019s much that is hopeful over the next four to six weeks.", "If we take all the precautions \u2014 ventilation, opening windows, testing, people upping their mask game \u2014 and the kids are vaccinated, there\u2019s a reasonable chance we can operate the schools safely. But it\u2019s probably not going to work where all that is not happening. There\u2019s this narrative that closing the schools was the biggest mistake of 2020, which I think kind of hardens everybody\u2019s position. Closing presents real hardships to kids and their parents. We also are looking at a really very large threat in terms of infection that probably will be gone by February. There\u2019s so much infection around now that there\u2019s a good chance someone will have Covid in a classroom of 20 kids.", "California was always doing better than Texas and Florida in per capita deaths, but today the per capita death rate in Texas is about 35 percent higher than California\u2019s. In Florida, it\u2019s 50 percent higher. Those are massive differences. If Texas and Florida had California\u2019s per capita death rate, they would each have 20,000 more people alive today. Forty thousand lives saved. To me, that\u2019s nontrivial.", "For more:", "Klete Keller was one of the world\u2019s elite freestyle swimmers in the 2000s, a University of Southern California standout who competed in three Olympics and won two gold medals. How, asks The Los Angeles Times, did he end up in the mob that stormed Congress last Jan. 6?", "Coconut rice with peas.", "Today\u2019s travel tip comes from Bonnie Powell, a reader who lives in the Bay Area:", "Tell us about your favorite places to visit in California. Email your suggestions to CAtoday@nytimes.com. We\u2019ll be sharing more in upcoming editions of the newsletter.", "How did you mark the start of the 2022?
